ticket.title: caching bugs in ActiveRecord#create and associations
ticket.original-body:
When `find_or_create` creates a record, it does not clear the cache like `create` does, causing some interesting anomalies.
Here is a quick example: http://pastie.org/278991
Enclosed is a rails app with a single test that confirms the problem.
ticket.latest-body:

Here is a quick example: http://pastie.org/278991
Enclosed is a rails app with a single test that confirms the problem.

version.title: find_or_create causes caching anomalies

version.body:
Looks like this isn't just a problem with find_or_create. I can cause a similar problem with regular create. It only takes a little bit of indirection on the very same association to screw things up.
Patch added contains tests that verify the problem
version.body-html:
Looks like this isn't just a problem with find_or_create. I can cause a similar problem with regular create. It only takes a little bit of indirection on the very same association to screw things up.

Patch added contains tests that verify the problem
version.title: caching bugs in ActiveRecord#create and associations

version.body:
I still have this issue today (Rails version 2.3.2).
The test code will explain what's wrong.
@@@ ruby class Page < ActiveRecord::Base acts_as_tree :counter_cache => :children_count end
@@@
Test: @@@ ruby require File.dirname(__FILE__) + '/../test_helper'
class PageTest < ActiveSupport::TestCase context "pages" do should "have a counter cache" do Page.root.children_count.should == 0 Page.root.children.create(:title => 'about') Page.root.children.count.should == 1 Page.root.children_count.should == 1 Page.root.children.find_or_create_by_title('contact') Page.root.children.count.should == 2 Page.root.children_count.should == 2 # false end end end
@@@
version.body-html:
I still have this issue today (Rails version 2.3.2).

The test code will explain what's wrong.

class Page < ActiveRecord::Base
  acts_as_tree :counter_cache => :children_count
end

Test:

require File.dirname(FILE) + '/../test_helper'







class PageTest < ActiveSupport::TestCase
  context "pages" do







should "have a counter cache" do
  Page.root.children_count.should == 0
  Page.root.children.create(:title => 'about')
  Page.root.children.count.should == 1
  Page.root.children_count.should == 1
  Page.root.children.find_or_create_by_title('contact')
  Page.root.children.count.should == 2
  Page.root.children_count.should == 2 # false
end





  end
end
version.title: caching bugs in ActiveRecord#create and associations

version.title: caching bugs in ActiveRecord#create and associations

version.body:
Just recapping.
@@@ ruby class Car has_many :brakes end
c = Car.first c.brakes # => 0 . so that all brakes are loaded c.brakes.find_or_create(:name => 'super_brake') # new brake is created c.brakes.length #=> 0 c.brakes.count #=> 1 @@@
when c.brakes.find_or_create is invoked then method_missing is called and method_missing simply does
@@@ ruby @reflection.klass.send(method, *args) { |*block_args| yield(*block_args) } @@@
In contrast when car.brakes.create(:name => 'super_brake') is called then add_record_to_target_with_callbacks is called
@@@ ruby def add_record_to_target_with_callbacks(record) callback(:before_add, record) yield(record) if block_given? @target ||= [] unless loaded? @target << record unless @reflection.options[:uniq] && @target.include?(record) callback(:after_add, record) set_inverse_instance(record, @owner) record end @@@
So not only cache is not getting refreshed but inverse_instance will also not be set.
version.body-html:
Just recapping.

class Car
  has_many :brakes
end

c = Car.first
c.brakes # => 0 . so that all brakes are loaded
c.brakes.find_or_create(:name => 'super_brake') # new brake is created
c.brakes.length #=> 0
c.brakes.count #=> 1

when c.brakes.find_or_create is invoked then method_missing is called and method_missing simply does

  @reflection.klass.send(method, *args) { |*block_args| yield(*block_args) }

In contrast when car.brakes.create(:name => 'super_brake') is called then add_record_to_target_with_callbacks is called

def add_record_to_target_with_callbacks(record)
   callback(:before_add, record)
   yield(record) if block_given?
   @target ||= [] unless loaded?
   @target << record unless @reflection.options[:uniq] && @target.include?(record)
   callback(:after_add, record)
   set_inverse_instance(record, @owner)
   record
 end

So not only cache is not getting refreshed but inverse_instance will also not be set.
version.title: caching bugs in ActiveRecord#create and associations

version.body: Added a patch with fixes and tests.
version.body-html: Added a patch with fixes and tests.

version.body-html: (from [d5921cdb7a00b393d0ba5f2f795da60a33b11cf1]) Remove unintentional API changes. [#1108] http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/d5921cdb7a00b393d0ba5f2f795da6...
version.title: caching bugs in ActiveRecord#create and associations

version.body:
[Commit fad166c15277c72b370c90e890d509d0f6c9af63](http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/fad166c15277c72b370c90e890d509d0f6c9af63) (i.e. 2.3.9) broke find_or_create_by_x with additional parameters for the create, when called through an association. Since http://dev.rubyonrails.org/ticket/7368 you've been able to pass additional parameters that are ignored by the find but used by the create. fad166c broke that behavior.
I'll attach a test case that demonstrates the problem, but in a nutshell:
@@@ ruby # 2.3.8: success # 2.3.9: ArgumentError: Unknown key(s): type, body # ./test/cases/../../../activesupport/lib/active_support/core_ext/hash/keys.rb:47:in `assert_valid_keys' post.comments.find_or_create_by_body(:body => 'other test comment body', :type => 'test') @@@
version.body-html:
Commit fad166c15277c72b370c90e890d509d0f6c9af63 (i.e. 2.3.9) broke find_or_create_by_x with additional parameters for the create, when called through an association. Since http://dev.rubyonrails.org/ticket/7368 you've been able to pass additional parameters that are ignored by the find but used by the create. fad166c broke that behavior.

I'll attach a test case that demonstrates the problem, but in a nutshell:

    # 2.3.8: success
    # 2.3.9: ArgumentError: Unknown key(s): type, body
    #     ./test/cases/../../../activesupport/lib/active_support/core_ext/hash/keys.rb:47:in `assert_valid_keys'
    post.comments.find_or_create_by_body(:body => 'other test comment body', :type => 'test')
version.title: caching bugs in ActiveRecord#create and associations

version.body: fad166c15277c72b370c90e890d509d0f6c9af63 also broke find_or_create_by_x with a block provided. It used to yield to the block but it doesn't anymore. I'll attach another test case that works with 2.3.8 but fails with 2.3.9. For example: @@@ ruby comment = post.comments.find_or_create_by_body('other test comment body') { |comment| comment.type = 'test' } @@@
version.body-html:
fad166c15277c72b370c90e890d509d0f6c9af63 also broke find_or_create_by_x with a block provided. It used to yield to the block but it doesn't anymore. I'll attach another test case that works with 2.3.8 but fails with 2.3.9. For example:

    comment = post.comments.find_or_create_by_body('other test comment body') { |comment| comment.type = 'test' }
version.title: caching bugs in ActiveRecord#create and associations

version.body: Here's a 2-part patch that fixes both problems. The gist of the first part of the patch is to filter parameters provided to a find_or_create_by_x method call so that we only pass the ones to find() that find() cares about. The second part adds code to yield to a provided block.
version.body-html: Here's a 2-part patch that fixes both problems. The gist of the first part of the patch is to filter parameters provided to a find_or_create_by_x method call so that we only pass the ones to find() that find() cares about. The second part adds code to yield to a provided block.
version.title: caching bugs in ActiveRecord#create and associations

version.body: Looks like I can't re-open this bug so I've opened #5737 to track the resolution of these bugs.
version.body-html: Looks like I can't re-open this bug so I've opened #5737 to track the resolution of these bugs.

version.body: This supra footwear is called a modern vintage and has been since their introduction in 2003 where they began in Europe. Every supra shoes has some type of ornament, adornment or hardware and is comprised of aged leather that is bought from around the world. These supra uk are culturally engaging and allow for the woman wearing them to be enveloped in luxury.With new cuts and styles and hand stitched shoes, these timberland boots, heels or flats will make every foot look like it stepped out of vintage Hollywood. This timberland shoes have been worn and coveted by many of the most famous females in recent history. One such coach outlet, Jennifer Aniston, wears them in public and at home.This company makes many different unique styles of bags outlet from ankle booties to sandals, pumps, moncler jackets online, platforms and wedges. One louis vuitton bag in particular is ideal for the gothic style sense; it is patent leather and laces up the front of the shaft. There are also zippers on each side, and this shoe offers a flat heel of a half inch.Another great moncler jackets sale is featured in People's Style Watch and is called a platform bootie. This ture religion jeans has a raised panel in front of the ankle as well as a heel that measures 4.5 inches. The front offers a leather bandage appearance and is considered high fashion.
